prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I tell my girlfriend she can’t bring her friend to my apartment anymore?
A little over a month ago my girlfriend and her parents got into a fight so she came to stay with me until they made up.  I was really clear that this was just temporary until they patched things up.  

It was going fine until she started bringing one of her friends over.   I had met this girl a few times before.  I thought she was ok.  

My girlfriend is like a totally different person around her.   They both get nasty.  Really catty.  There have been a bunch of times that it’s bothered me.  

There was one time I came home and it suddenly got quiet as soon as I came in.  It was awkward so just to break the silence I said something like, “I’m beat” and they both busted out laughing hysterically.   I asked my girlfriend what was so funny and she just told me nothing.  It was kinda obvious that were laughing at my expense, whatever. 

Another time I was in my bedroom and came to the kitchen to make a sandwich.  They were in the living room.  I wasn’t paying attention to what they were saying.  I have no idea what it was about.  I thought it’d be nice to offer to make them some snacks so I started to offer and girlfriend’s friend cut me off and said, “shocker the MAN has to have an opinion about it” in a really nasty way.  I thought to myself “well fuck you too”, but just said “actually nope” and took my sandwich back to my bedroom. 

The situation that sent me over the edge though happened yesterday.   It was my last day off and I wasn’t able to relax much on Monday.   I was in the living room playing a game and they came over.  Girlfriend asked if they could have the room and I go to the bedroom.   I said “nah I’m right in the middle of this, can you guys hang out in the bedroom?”   Friend gave the most sour ducking look and my girlfriend got an attitude.  “It’s just a stupid game, you can play it anytime”.  So I said, “ yeah I can play it anytime and I’m playing it now”.  Friend mumbled something I couldn’t hear and they went to the bedroom.  It’s a small apartment and I could hear them both bitch about me even with the tv on.  

My girlfriend is usually such a sweet and funny person, but when her friend is around it’s like a switch flips and she’s a totally different person.  I don’t get it.   I don’t really want to, I just don’t want to deal with it anymore.  I want to tell her not to bring her friend here anymore.  Also maybe start pushing her to try talking to her parents again.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's tackle this. The user is asking if the author (the person in the WIBTA post) is in the wrong for not wanting his girlfriend to bring her friend to his apartment anymore.

First, I need to understand the situation. The girlfriend moved in temporarily after a fight with her parents. The author allowed this as a temporary arrangement. Then the girlfriend starts bringing her friend, and things start to get tense. The author gives examples of awkward interactions and the friend being rude. The friend and girlfriend act differently around him, and the author feels uncomfortable.

So the main issue is whether the author is justified in asking the girlfriend to stop bringing her friend. The user thinks the author is in the wrong, but I need to evaluate both sides.

The author's perspective: He's in his own apartment, so he has the right to control who's there. The friend's behavior is rude, and the girlfriend's behavior changes when the friend is around. The author is frustrated and wants to set boundaries. It's reasonable for him to feel that he shouldn't have to tolerate the friend's negativity or the girlfriend's attitude when the friend is present. The author is also considering pushing the girlfriend to reconcile with her parents, which might be part of the solution.

The girlfriend's perspective: She's in a difficult situation with her parents, and the friend might be a source of support for her. Bringing the friend over might not be malicious; maybe it's a way for her to cope. However, the friend's behavior is clearly problematic. The girlfriend might not realize how her friend is acting around the author. The issue could be that the girlfriend is under stress, and the friend is amplifying that stress.

The key points here are the author's right to his living space and the girlfriend's responsibility to manage her friend's behavior. The author has set boundaries from the start (temporary stay), and the friend's presence is causing conflict. The author is within his rights to ask the girlfriend to respect his space and stop bringing someone who is causing issues. The girl's friend's behavior is unkind, and the girlfriend's attitude is affected by her. The author has a right to expect that guests don't make him uncomfortable. However, he should communicate this clearly and with empathy, not just unilaterally decide without discussing with his girlfriend. But the main question is if he's in the wrong for wanting to set these boundaries. 

Also, the girlfriend's friend's remarks were clearly disrespectful. The author's examples show that the friend is unkind, and the girlfriend isn't standing up for him. So the author's decision might be necessary for his own comfort and mental well-being. The fact that the girlfriend is changing her behavior around the friend is a red flag. The author is not being unreasonable in this case. So the answer is B, the author is not in the wrong.
